subject: Travel
subcategory: The Story of Maps and Navigation
title: Dead Reckoning
description: A quick, practical guide to Dead Reckoning.

hook.text: Before GPS, pilots and sailors guessed their position by tracking speed, direction, and time. It was called dead reckoning.

buildup.text: Sailors threw a log overboard and timed how fast the rope unwound. That's where 'knots' comes from.

discovery.text: Pilots in World War II used dead reckoning to navigate across featureless oceans for hours.

twist.text: Errors compound with every calculation. After hours, positions could be off by hundreds of miles.

climax.text: Modern inertial navigation systems use the same principle but with gyroscopes and accelerometers.

punchline.text: Guessing your way across the ocean had a fancy name: dead reckoning.

quiz.question: Where does the nautical term 'knots' come from?
options: Timing knots on a rope pulled by a log in the water
